Yes, I certainly think that many of the negative consequences of the industrial revolution could have been avoided if there were proper regulations in place at the time. During the early phases of the industrial revolution, there were few, if any, government regulations in place to protect workers, the environment or society. As a result, companies could operate with virtually no restrictions or oversight, leading to the negative consequences that we now associate with early industrialization.

If regulations had been in place, it is possible that many of these negative consequences could have been avoided. For example, regulations on minimum wage, working conditions, and maximum number of work hours could have led to better living and working conditions for factory workers. Similarly, restrictions on pollution and deforestation activities could have helped to reduce the environmental damage caused by industrialization.

Going forward, governments around the world recognized the importance of regulations to ensure that society as a whole benefits from technological advancements while minimizing the negative impacts. This has led to a more balanced and sustainable approach to economic development that takes into account social and environmental concerns.
